oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Steve Wariner Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: The recording is of an interview with Steve Wariner (performer) conducted by Biff Collie. Segment is recorded on an unknown date. Segment is part of the Music City Album Review.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Steve Wariner; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Steve Wariner introduces himself, and Wariner and Biff Collie joke about the circumstances of Wariner's birth -- (00:35) Wariner and Collie discuss Wariner's musical upbringing, and Wariner being a disc jockey -- (01:30) "I Got Dreams" is joked about by Wariner and Collie for its lack of grammar -- (02:08) Wariner reflects on CD technology and recalls how "Where Did I go Wrong" was written -- (02:39) Collie asks if Wariner is a 'ladies man' based on his song "I Could Get Lucky Tonight" -- (03:34) Wariner reflects on writing with Don Schlitz and the recording process -- (05:09) "Nothin' in the World (Gonna Keep Me from You)" is told by Wariner to have been from a session with Mike Reid, and Wariner and Collie discuss Reid -- (06:57) Wariner discusses how he began writing "When I Could Come Home to You" on the road -- (07:31) Collie and Wariner discuss Wariner's writing process -- (08:41) Wariner reflects on the importance of having honest people around you -- (09:03) Wariner reflects on watching professionals work -- (09:35) Collie invites Wariner to discuss Wariner's uniqueness in being a singer-songwriter, and Wariner remembers a time where he hurt his metacarpal -- (11:32) "Language of Love" is told by Wariner to be about being a tourist -- (12:16) Collie introduces Wariner's musical upbringing -- (12:36) "The Loser Wins" is told by Wariner to be about how having a girlfriend changes a man, and Collie inquires about Wariner's writing process -- (13:58) Collie introduces "Do You Wanna Make Something of It" and Wariner says there in not much of a story behind the song -- (14:35) Collie and Wariner joke about the inspiration behind "Plano Texas Girl," and both discuss Terry and David Wariner -- (18:07) Wariner reveals "The Flower That Shattered the Stone" is the only song on the album he did not write -- (18:56) Collie expresses his thanks, and Wariner and Collie say their thanks -- (19:20) Collie asks Wariner who he would enjoy writing with -- (19:46) Wariner reveals basketball is a second passion of his -- (21:29) Wariner reflects on keeping level-headed with celebrity status -- (22:35) Wariner recalls the first time he performed live (for a barn-dance) -- (24:27) Wariner recalls meeting Dickey Lee, and others, while young, and Wariner reflects on aspiring artists -- (26:06) Wariner discusses how he was able to perform for Dottie West -- (27:54) Wariner tells that originally wished to be a guitar player, and Wariner and Collie reflect on Bob Luman -- (30:03) Collie recaps Wariner's talents and Wariner tells he does not have the time to keep his hobbies up -- (32:47) Collie inquires about Wariner using magic in a music video, and Wariner tells about his aspirations in magic -- (33:45) Wariner discusses how he met Chet Atkins -- (37:13) Wariner and Collie discuss Wariner recording with Atkins -- (37:47) Wariner's reveals his first record was "I'm Already Taken" -- (38:14) "Your Memory" is revealed to be Wariner's first number one record -- (39:18) Wariner and Collie discuss Wariner's records and how Wariner does not pay attention to his accolades -- (39:57) Wariner reveals the various pranks he and his band did -- (40:53) Wariner reflects on the acceptance of the country music industry -- (42:06) Wariner says 'Bush likes country music, I like that' -- (42:13) Collie introduces Wariner's family and Wariner describes his interactions with his family -- (44:03) Wariner says his goodbye
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Wariner, Steve; Collie, Biff;
